title: The trade environment makes the possibility of trade deals remote
text:
India is currently engaged in two important trade negotiations. They are the limited trade agreement with US and the finalization of the Regional Comprehensive Economic Partnership (RCEP).

It is reasonable to assume at this stage that a successful outcome on both agreements is unlikely at this point in time. Even if all stakeholders believe a deal represents a step forward, reaching one hasn’t been harder in almost two decades.

To put that gloomy conclusion in perspective, it is necessary to take a look at the overall environment for global trade.

It is dismal.

To illustrate, the World Trade Organization’s annual report for 2019 shows that the challenges confronting trade negotiators across the world are getting tougher.

According to WTO’s Director-General Roberto Azevedo, the year 2018 was a tough one because of mounting trade tensions, an increase in trade restrictive measures and continuing economic uncertainty.

In 2017, merchandise trade grew at 4.6%. The next year the growth rate dropped to 3%. In the current year it is forecast to grow at 2.6%.

WTO does not expect a dramatic turnaround the next year.

One aspect of WTO’s trade data is an insightful measure of the obstacles to a trade deal caused by mounting trade tensions.

In 2018, WTO members initiated 38 new disputes, which was more than twice the number of disputes initiated in 2017.

Since WTO’s entry into force in 1995, 2018 recorded the third largest number of annual dispute filings. Things haven’t been this bad since 1998.

Juxtapose the WTO dispute data with an observation by US Commerce Secretary Wilbur Ross last week that India is a protectionist country, the possibility of a limited trade deal with US seems difficult to pull off at this time.
